newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: No clean sweep for Singapore's PAP in election.
newsitem.headline: No clean sweep for Singapore's PAP in election.

text.p: Two incumbent opposition members have won re-election to Singapore's parliament, dashing ruling People's Action Party (PAP) hopes of a clean sweep, according to official results announced early on Friday.
But in other single-member districts, the PAP knocked out two opposition incumbents seeking another term in Thursday's general election.
Workers' Party candidate Low Thia Khian and Singapore People's Party candidate Chiam See Tong each held onto their seats. The Singapore Democratic Party's two incumbents lost.
Earlier it was announced that Singapore Democratic Party leader Chee Soon Juan was also soundly defeated in his bid for a seat in parliament.
The PAP also won the other six single-member constituencies at stake in the election, and one four-member multi-member constituency.

Returns from 18 other seats up for grabs in Thursday's election were to be announced later. The PAP had already taken 47 seats in the 83-member parliament on Nomination Day December 23, when the opposition failed to contest them.
